born London, April 2, 1894; died London, October 7, 1969

div.p: Oldman worked at the British Museum in London from 1920 to 1957, first as an assistant keeper and later as principal keeper in the Department of Printed Books, with a special interest in music books. His expertise in the bibliography of Haydn, Beethoven, and particularly of Mozart was internationally recognized. With Otto Erich Deutsch in 1931‒32 he published a "bibliographical extension to Köchel's list of [Mozart's] works," a copy of which Deutsch seems to have sent Schenker on June 4, 1932 (Schenker's diary, June 4 and 5).

Anthony van Hoboken wrote to Schenker on July 31, 1934 that Deutsch wanted to publish works on first and early editions in a series that Oldman was planning, which had indirectly created conflict between Deutsch and Hoboken (OJ 89/7, [12]).
